1.name: Awareness
1.description: You recognize that health is foundational to everything else
capabilities: Recognize sleep debt and energy patterns
Know the cost of neglecting health
1.milestone: Track sleep for one week and identify patterns

2.name: Foundation
2.milestone: Maintain 7+ hours sleep for 2 weeks straight

3.name: Habit Builder
3.milestone: Exercise 3x per week for one month

4.name: Consistent Practitioner
4.description: Reliable health practices regardless of circumstances
4.milestone: Maintain health habits through a stressful period

5.name: Optimizer
5.milestone: Implement one advanced health protocol (cold exposure, fasting, etc.)

6.name: Peak Performer
6.description: High energy and performance is the norm
capabilities: Mental clarity most of the day

7.name: Biohacker
7.description: Using data and experimentation to optimize
7.milestone: Complete a 30-day health experiment with measurable results

8.name: Health Athlete
capabilities: Recovery is as prioritized as training
8.milestone: Complete a physical challenge that seemed impossible 2 years ago

9.name: Longevity Player
9.description: Playing the long game for healthspan
9.milestone: Biological age tests younger than chronological age

10.name: Health Master
10.milestone: Health is something you no longer think about - it just works

beginner.title: Sleep Audit
beginner.instructions: Track your sleep for one week: bed time, wake time, quality (1-10), energy next day (1-10). Identify: What affects sleep quality? What's your optimal sleep duration? What's stealing your sleep?
beginner.success_criteria: 7-day sleep log with patterns identified and one change to implement

beginner.title: Morning Sunlight Protocol
beginner.instructions: Within 30 minutes of waking, get 10 minutes of natural sunlight (not through windows). Do this for 7 consecutive days. Note your energy and mood.
beginner.success_criteria: 7 consecutive days of morning sunlight with noted effects

beginner.title: Hydration Reset
beginner.instructions: For one week, drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking, and track total water intake. Aim for at least 2 liters daily. Notice energy and focus changes.
beginner.success_criteria: 7 days of tracked water intake with energy observations

intermediate.title: Cold Exposure Introduction
intermediate.instructions: End your regular shower with 30 seconds of cold water. Build to 2 minutes over 2 weeks. Focus on breathing through the discomfort. This builds resilience and improves mood.
intermediate.success_criteria: 2 weeks of daily cold exposure with documented progression

intermediate.title: Sleep Optimization Sprint
intermediate.instructions: Implement the sleep optimization protocol: Room at 65-68°F, blackout curtains, no screens 1 hour before bed, no caffeine after 2pm, no alcohol, consistent bed/wake time. Measure impact.
intermediate.success_criteria: Full protocol implemented for 1 week with sleep quality ratings

intermediate.title: Zone 2 Cardio Baseline
intermediate.instructions: Do 30 minutes of Zone 2 cardio (can hold conversation, nose breathing possible). Could be walking, cycling, swimming. Track heart rate if possible. Do 3x this week.
intermediate.success_criteria: 3 Zone 2 sessions completed with heart rate data or perceived exertion

advanced.title: Complete Health Protocol Audit
advanced.instructions: Audit all aspects: Sleep (quality, duration, consistency), Nutrition (macros, timing, quality), Exercise (cardio, strength, mobility), Stress (management, recovery), Supplementation. Score each 1-10. Create improvement plan for lowest areas.
advanced.success_criteria: Full health audit with scores and 90-day improvement plan

advanced.title: Time-Restricted Eating Experiment
advanced.instructions: Implement 16:8 intermittent fasting (16 hour fast, 8 hour eating window) for 2 weeks. Track: energy, hunger, focus, sleep quality, any challenges. Evaluate if this protocol works for you.
advanced.success_criteria: 14 days of TRE with documented effects and decision about continuation

advanced.title: Build Your Centenarian Decathlon
advanced.instructions: Following Peter Attia's framework: Define 10 physical activities you want to be able to do at age 100 (play with grandkids, carry groceries up stairs, etc.). Work backward to determine what training you need NOW to maintain that capacity.
advanced.success_criteria: Centenarian decathlon defined with current training program aligned

cross_module_connections.insight: Energy management is more important than time management - you can't focus your way out of exhaustion
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Track your energy levels hourly for 3 days. Schedule your most important work for your peak energy windows.

cross_module_connections.insight: Physical discomfort training (cold, exercise) directly builds mental toughness
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Use your cold shower as a Stoic practice - 30 seconds of voluntary discomfort to start each day.

cross_module_connections.insight: Your environment determines your health choices - make healthy the default
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Stock your kitchen with only foods you want to eat. Remove the decision-making that leads to poor choices.

cross_module_connections.insight: Health is the ultimate wealth - without it, nothing else matters
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Calculate what you spend on health (gym, food quality, supplements) as an investment, not an expense.

masters.name: Andrew Huberman
key_principles: Get sunlight in your eyes within the first hour of waking. It sets your circadian rhythm.
Avoid bright lights between 10pm and 4am. It suppresses melatonin and disrupts sleep.
Non-sleep deep rest (NSDR) is a powerful tool for recovery and focus.
Cold exposure increases dopamine by 250% for hours. It builds resilience.
Caffeine should be delayed 90-120 minutes after waking for optimal energy.
Exercise is the most powerful tool we have for brain health and neuroplasticity.

worked_examples.title: The Huberman Morning Protocol
worked_examples.scenario: You wake up groggy and rely on caffeine to function, but crash by afternoon.
step_by_step: Wake at consistent time: Anchor your circadian rhythm
First 10 minutes: Get outside, get sunlight in your eyes (not through glass)
Movement: Light walking or exercise outdoors amplifies the light effect
Delay caffeine: Wait 90-120 minutes to let adenosine clear naturally
Cold exposure: End shower with 1-2 minutes cold for dopamine boost
First caffeine: Now it works better and lasts longer
Result: Natural energy, no afternoon crash, better sleep that night
worked_examples.outcome: Sustainable energy throughout the day without the crash. Sleep improves because circadian rhythm is properly set.

scripts_templates.title: Morning Sunlight Protocol Template
scripts_templates.context: Use within 30-60 minutes of waking to set your circadian rhythm
scripts_templates.template:
IDEAL PROTOCOL:
- Within 30 min of waking: Get outside
- Duration: 10 minutes (cloudy) to 5 minutes (sunny)
- Eyes: Face toward sun direction (don't stare at sun)
- Glass: Does NOT count - must be direct sunlight
- Sunglasses: No - light needs to hit eyes

VARIATIONS:
- If cloudy: Double the time (20 min)
- If raining: Still beneficial, face window while drinking coffee
- If very early/dark: Use 10,000 lux light box for 10 min

STACKING:
- Combine with morning walk
- Combine with outdoor coffee
- Combine with morning journaling outside

TRACKING:
[ ] Mon [ ] Tue [ ] Wed [ ] Thu [ ] Fri [ ] Sat [ ] Sun
Energy rating: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
Week 1 Log:
[x] Mon - 8 min sunny, felt great by 9am
[x] Tue - 15 min cloudy, noticed less need for coffee
[x] Wed - 12 min, combined with walk
[x] Thu - 10 min, cold but worth it
[x] Fri - Missed (rushed), felt difference all day
[x] Sat - 20 min, went for walk
[x] Sun - 15 min on porch with coffee

Energy: Noticeably better by day 4. Friday showed how much I now rely on this.

scripts_templates.title: Sleep Optimization Checklist
scripts_templates.template:
EVENING (2 hours before bed):
[ ] Dim lights after sunset
[ ] No screens 1 hour before bed (or use blue blockers)
[ ] No caffeine after 2pm
[ ] No alcohol (or 3+ hours before bed)
[ ] Room temperature: 65-68°F (18-20°C)

BEDROOM SETUP:
[ ] Pitch black (blackout curtains)
[ ] No blue/white light from devices
[ ] Phone charging outside room (or airplane mode)
[ ] Cool temperature
[ ] Clean, organized space

TIMING:
[ ] Consistent bed time: ___
[ ] Consistent wake time: ___
[ ] 7-8 hours sleep opportunity

IF HAVING TROUBLE:
- NSDR (non-sleep deep rest) protocol on YouTube
- 20 min magnesium threonate before bed
- No food 3 hours before bed
- Write down tomorrow's worries before bed
scripts_templates.example_filled:
My sleep stack:
- 8pm: Dim lights, orange bulbs in bedroom
- 9pm: No more screens
- 9:30pm: Reading or stretching
- 10pm: In bed
- Room: 67°F, blackout curtains, phone in living room
- 6am: Wake same time every day (even weekends)

Result: Sleep quality went from 5 to 8 in 2 weeks

books.title: Huberman Lab Podcast
books.author: Andrew Huberman
books.key_takeaway: Comprehensive science-based protocols for all aspects of health (free resource)

podcasts.title: Huberman Lab
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep-dive episodes on sleep, exercise, dopamine, and every health topic

masters.name: Matthew Walker
key_principles: Sleep is the single most effective thing you can do to reset your brain and body.
Routinely sleeping less than 6 hours a night weakens your immune system substantially.
The shorter your sleep, the shorter your life.
There is no major organ in the body or brain that isn't enhanced by sleep.
REM sleep is critical for emotional regulation and creativity.
Alcohol is one of the most powerful suppressors of REM sleep.
daily_practices: Keep a consistent sleep schedule, even weekends
Avoid alcohol and caffeine before bed

worked_examples.title: The Sleep Debt Recovery Plan
worked_examples.scenario: You've been sleeping 5-6 hours for weeks and feel it accumulating.
step_by_step: Acknowledge: You can't fully 'catch up' but can recover substantially
Weekend extension: Sleep until you wake naturally (no alarm) to assess true need
Set consistent schedule: Go to bed and wake at same time every day
Prioritize: Treat 8 hours sleep as non-negotiable for 2 weeks
Environment: Optimize bedroom (cool, dark, quiet)
No alcohol: Even 'moderate' drinking destroys REM sleep
After 2 weeks: Assess energy, mood, cognition - they should all improve
worked_examples.outcome: After 2 weeks of prioritized sleep, you'll realize how impaired you were. This becomes your new normal.

scripts_templates.title: Sleep Quality Assessment
scripts_templates.context: Use weekly to track and improve sleep
scripts_templates.template:
WEEK OF: ___

METRICS:
- Average bed time: ___
- Average wake time: ___
- Average hours: ___
- Days hitting 7+ hours: ___/7

QUALITY INDICATORS:
- Fall asleep within 20 min? [ ] Yes [ ] No
- Wake up feeling refreshed? [ ] Yes [ ] No
- No waking during night? [ ] Yes [ ] No
- Dream recall (indicates REM)? [ ] Yes [ ] No

DISRUPTORS THIS WEEK:
- Alcohol: ___ nights
- Late caffeine: ___ days
- Screens in bed: ___ nights
- Irregular schedule: ___ nights

LAST WEEK'S CHANGE: ___
RESULT: ___

THIS WEEK'S FOCUS: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
WEEK OF: Jan 27 - Feb 2

METRICS:
- Bed: 10:30pm avg
- Wake: 6:30am avg
- Hours: 7.5 avg
- Days 7+ hours: 6/7

QUALITY:
[x] Fall asleep quickly
[x] Refreshed mornings
[ ] Some waking (usually 3am)
[x] Dream recall 4/7 nights

DISRUPTORS:
- Alcohol: 2 nights (Friday, Saturday)
- Late caffeine: 1 day (Wednesday meeting)
- Screens in bed: 0
- Irregular schedule: 1 (Friday late)

LAST WEEK'S CHANGE: Removed phone from bedroom
RESULT: Fell asleep faster, less morning scrolling

THIS WEEK'S FOCUS: No alcohol to compare REM quality

books.title: Why We Sleep
books.author: Matthew Walker
books.key_takeaway: The comprehensive science of sleep and why you need more of it

masters.name: Peter Attia
key_principles: The four horsemen of chronic disease: heart disease, cancer, neurodegenerative disease, metabolic disease.
Zone 2 cardio is the foundation of metabolic health and longevity.
Muscle is the organ of longevity. Preserve and build it.
Stability and mobility decline with age unless actively maintained.
What you do in your 40s determines your health in your 80s.
Emotional health is the fifth horseman. Don't neglect it.
daily_practices: Focus on stability and mobility, not just strength

worked_examples.title: The Centenarian Decathlon
worked_examples.scenario: You want to be healthy and functional at 100, not just alive.
step_by_step: Define your 'marginal decade': The last decade of your life (90-100, or 85-95)
List 10 activities you want to do in that decade: Play with grandkids, carry groceries upstairs, get up from floor, etc.
Work backward: What physical capacity do those require?
Account for decline: You'll lose 10-15% per decade. What do you need NOW?
Example: To carry 20 lbs up stairs at 90, you might need to lift 80 lbs now
Design training: Create program that builds/maintains required capacity
The key insight: Start building now because you'll lose capacity over time
worked_examples.outcome: Training becomes purposeful - you're not just exercising, you're building the capacity to live fully in your final decades.

scripts_templates.title: Centenarian Decathlon Design
scripts_templates.context: Plan physical capacity for your final decade of life
scripts_templates.template:
MY TARGET 'MARGINAL DECADE': Age ___ to ___

10 ACTIVITIES I WANT TO DO:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___
4. ___
5. ___
6. ___
7. ___
8. ___
9. ___
10. ___

PHYSICAL REQUIREMENTS:
(What capacity does each require?)
1. ___
2. ___
[etc.]

CURRENT CAPACITY vs. REQUIRED:
(With 10-15% decline per decade factored in)

CARDIO:
- Required at 90: ___
- Required now: ___
- Current: ___
- Gap: ___

STRENGTH:
- Required at 90: ___
- Required now: ___
- Current: ___
- Gap: ___

MOBILITY:
- Required at 90: ___
- Required now: ___
- Current: ___
- Gap: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
TARGET: Age 90-100

10 ACTIVITIES:
1. Play actively with great-grandchildren
2. Carry groceries (20 lbs) up a flight of stairs
3. Get up from floor without assistance
4. Walk 18 holes of golf
5. Swim in the ocean
6. Travel independently (carry luggage)
7. Maintain my garden
8. Cook standing for 30 minutes
9. Hike 3 miles on varied terrain
10. Dance at family weddings

REQUIREMENTS:
- Cardiovascular: Maintain Zone 2 for 45+ minutes
- Lower body: Squat bodyweight, deadlift 1.5x BW
- Upper body: Carry 40 lbs, push up from floor
- Mobility: Full range hip hinge, overhead reach
- Balance: Single leg stand 30 seconds

CURRENT vs REQUIRED (age 45):
Cardio: Need 25 min zone 2 at 90 → Need 45 min now → Currently 30 min → GAP: Build up
Strength: Need 100 lb deadlift at 90 → Need 200 lb now → Currently 185 → Close, maintain
Mobility: Need floor sit-to-stand → Need full squat now → Currently tight hips → GAP: Priority

scripts_templates.title: Zone 2 Cardio Protocol
scripts_templates.context: Build metabolic health through proper aerobic training
scripts_templates.template:
WHAT IS ZONE 2:
Intensity where you can hold a conversation but it's getting difficult.
Typically: 60-70% of max heart rate
Nose breathing: Possible but challenging

TEST YOUR ZONE 2:
- Max HR estimate: 220 - age = ___
- Zone 2 range: 60-70% = ___ to ___
- Or use talk test: Can speak sentences, not paragraphs

WEEKLY TARGET: 3-4 hours total
Example: 4 x 45 min sessions

ACTIVITIES:
- Walking (brisk uphill)
- Cycling (easy pace)
- Swimming (continuous laps)
- Rowing (sustainable pace)

PROGRESSION:
Week 1: 3 x 30 min
Week 2: 3 x 35 min
Week 3: 3 x 40 min
Week 4: 4 x 40 min
[Build to 4 x 45-60 min]

KEY: If you can't hold a conversation, you're going too hard.
scripts_templates.example_filled:
MY ZONE 2:
Age: 40
Max HR: 180
Zone 2: 108-126 bpm

WEEKLY PLAN:
- Mon: 45 min cycling (trainer), avg 115 bpm
- Wed: 45 min brisk walk (hills), avg 118 bpm
- Sat: 60 min easy hike, avg 110 bpm
- Sun: 30 min swim, perceived easy effort

Total: 3 hours

PROGRESS:
Week 1: Hard to stay in zone, wanted to push
Week 4: Feels natural, pace is faster at same HR
Week 8: Noticeable improvement in recovery

books.title: Outlive: The Science and Art of Longevity
books.author: Peter Attia
books.key_takeaway: Comprehensive guide to extending healthspan, not just lifespan

podcasts.title: The Drive
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dives into longevity, medicine, and performance

masters.name: Rhonda Patrick
key_principles: Time-restricted eating can improve metabolic health significantly.
Sulforaphane (from broccoli sprouts) is one of the most powerful natural compounds.
Omega-3 fatty acids are critical for brain health and reducing inflammation.
Heat shock proteins from sauna use improve cardiovascular and brain health.
Vitamin D deficiency is widespread and linked to many chronic diseases.
Exercise creates new brain cells. It's the closest thing to a fountain of youth.

worked_examples.title: Implementing Time-Restricted Eating
worked_examples.scenario: You eat from 7am to 10pm, snacking throughout. Energy is inconsistent.
step_by_step: Current state: 15+ hour eating window, likely metabolic stress
Goal: 10-12 hour eating window, aligned with circadian rhythm
Start gradual: Compress by 30 min per week
Week 1: 8am - 9pm (13 hours)
Week 2: 8am - 8pm (12 hours)
Week 3: 9am - 8pm (11 hours)
Week 4: 9am - 7pm (10 hours)
Key: Last meal 3 hours before bed for sleep quality
Note: This isn't about calories - it's about metabolic rest
worked_examples.outcome: Improved metabolic flexibility, better sleep, more stable energy, potential body composition improvements.

scripts_templates.title: Nutrition Foundation Checklist
scripts_templates.context: Basic nutrition principles to optimize health
scripts_templates.template:
DAILY PRIORITIES:

PROTEIN:
[ ] 1g per lb of ideal body weight
[ ] Protein at every meal
[ ] Target: ___ grams/day

OMEGA-3s:
[ ] Fatty fish 2-3x/week (salmon, sardines, mackerel)
[ ] Or: Quality fish oil supplement (2-3g EPA+DHA)

VEGETABLES:
[ ] Cruciferous vegetables daily (broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage)
[ ] Leafy greens daily
[ ] Variety of colors

MINIMIZE:
[ ] Ultra-processed foods
[ ] Refined sugar
[ ] Industrial seed oils

VITAMIN D:
[ ] Get blood levels tested (target: 40-60 ng/mL)
[ ] Supplement if needed (most people do)

FIBER:
[ ] 30+ grams daily from whole foods

EATING WINDOW:
[ ] Consistent eating window: ___ to ___
[ ] No eating 3 hours before bed
scripts_templates.example_filled:
MY DAILY TARGETS:

PROTEIN: 160g (I weigh 180, want to be 160)
- Breakfast: 40g (eggs, Greek yogurt)
- Lunch: 50g (chicken or fish)
- Dinner: 50g (meat or fish)
- Snack: 20g (protein shake or cottage cheese)

OMEGA-3s:
- Salmon: Tuesday, Thursday
- Sardines: Saturday (with eggs)
- Fish oil: Other days (3g)

VEGETABLES:
- Broccoli or cauliflower with lunch
- Large salad with dinner
- Spinach in morning smoothie

EATING WINDOW: 8am - 6pm (10 hours)

WEEKLY PREP:
- Sunday: Prep proteins and vegetables for week
- This makes it automatic

books.title: FoundMyFitness Website
books.author: Rhonda Patrick
books.key_takeaway: Free, comprehensive articles on nutrition and health optimization

podcasts.title: FoundMyFitness Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dives into nutrition science and longevity research

masters.name: Wim Hof
key_principles: The cold is your warm friend.
Breathwork can directly influence your autonomic nervous system.
We can consciously influence our immune response through practice.
Discomfort is the way. Embrace it.
The mind is the master. The body will follow.
Go into the cold. It will show you who you really are.
daily_practices: End showers with 30-60 seconds of cold

worked_examples.title: Building a Cold Exposure Practice
worked_examples.scenario: You want to try cold exposure but the idea of cold water terrifies you.
step_by_step: Week 1: End regular shower with 15 seconds cold. Just 15. Breathe through it.
Week 2: 30 seconds cold. Focus on your breath, not the cold.
Week 3: 45 seconds cold. Notice it's getting easier.
Week 4: 60 seconds cold. You're now someone who does cold exposure.
Key technique: Breathe slowly and deeply. Don't gasp or hyperventilate.
Mental: Tell yourself 'I am in control' during exposure
After: Notice the 2-3 hour dopamine and energy boost
worked_examples.outcome: Cold becomes a tool, not a threat. You've built resilience that transfers to other challenges.

scripts_templates.title: Cold Exposure Progression Protocol
scripts_templates.context: Build cold tolerance gradually and safely
scripts_templates.template:
SAFETY FIRST:
- Never do cold water near electrical equipment
- Never hyperventilate then submerge (shallow water blackout risk)
- Start with shower, progress to bath/ice bath later
- Stop if you feel numbness, confusion, or extreme discomfort

WEEK 1: 15 seconds cold end to regular shower
- Breathe deeply, don't panic
- Focus: Just survive it

WEEK 2: 30 seconds
- Begin to relax into it
- Focus: Control your breath

WEEK 3: 45 seconds
- Notice it's getting easier
- Focus: Embrace the sensation

WEEK 4: 60 seconds
- You're now a 'cold person'
- Focus: Enjoy the afterglow

WEEK 5+: 2 minutes or progress to ice bath

BREATHING PROTOCOL:
- Before: 3 deep breaths
- During: Long exhales, controlled
- After: Normal breathing, notice energy

MINDSET:
'I am in control. This is my choice. I am getting stronger.'
scripts_templates.example_filled:
MY PROGRESS:

Week 1: 15 sec - HATED it, gasped, survived
Week 2: 30 sec - Still hard but found breath control
Week 3: 45 sec - Turned down temp further, feeling powerful
Week 4: 60 sec - Actually kind of enjoy it now??
Week 6: 2 min - This is just part of my morning now

BENEFITS NOTICED:
- Alert immediately after (no coffee needed)
- Better mood all morning
- Feel mentally tougher in other situations
- Cold weather doesn't bother me as much

scripts_templates.title: Wim Hof Breathing Method
scripts_templates.context: Practice breathwork for energy, focus, and resilience
scripts_templates.template:
PROTOCOL (do on empty stomach):

ROUND 1-3:
1. 30-40 deep breaths:
   - Inhale fully through nose or mouth
   - Exhale passive release (don't force)
   - Pace: Controlled but fairly fast

2. Retention:
   - After last exhale, hold breath
   - Time: As long as comfortable (often 1-2 min)
   - Stay relaxed, don't strain

3. Recovery breath:
   - Inhale fully, hold 15 seconds
   - Release
   - Begin next round

SENSATIONS (normal):
- Tingling in hands/feet
- Light-headedness
- Temperature changes

WARNINGS:
- Never do in water or while driving
- Stop if you feel faint
- Don't force retention times

RECOMMENDED: Use guided audio for first month
scripts_templates.example_filled:
MY SESSION TODAY:

Round 1: 35 breaths, held 1:15
Round 2: 38 breaths, held 1:45
Round 3: 40 breaths, held 2:10

Felt: Tingling in hands, very calm after

Schedule: Every morning before shower

books.title: The Wim Hof Method
books.author: Wim Hof
books.key_takeaway: Comprehensive guide to cold exposure and breathing practices

podcasts.title: Wim Hof on Joe Rogan
podcasts.key_takeaway: Introduction to the method and the science behind it

daily_insights: Sleep is when your brain cleans itself. Shortcut it at your peril.
Your body is adapting to whatever you consistently do. Make it count.
Energy is not something you have. It's something you create through habits.
The best workout is the one you actually do consistently.
Sunlight, movement, and sleep are free. Use them.
Recovery is when gains happen. Training is just the stimulus.
You can't outwork a bad diet or outsupplement bad sleep.
Small daily health habits compound into massive long-term results.
Your energy level dictates everything else. Protect it.
The body keeps the score. Take care of it.
skill_challenges: Get 10 minutes of sunlight within 1 hour of waking.
End your shower with 30 seconds of cold water.
Track your sleep for one week. Identify one improvement.
Drink 2 liters of water today. Notice your energy.
Go to bed 30 minutes earlier tonight.
Do 5 minutes of stretching or mobility work.
Eat protein with every meal today.
No screens 1 hour before bed tonight.
Do 3 minutes of deep breathing exercises.
